11.text: (Tim Hosking) The Macquarie Marshes Wetlands system is

14.text: a huge water dependent complex environment.

17.text: It’s something that at an international, national and state

20.text: and local level we’ve chosen to support.

23.text: (Debbie Love) Very significant because of its size and its location

28.text: out in semi-arid Australia. And it’s really important

34.text: the whole of the south east of Australia.

37.text: (Peter McLellan) I remember the marshes pre-Burrendong,

40.text: very lucky to be in part of that and be able to remember it

44.text: because it was a very significant place.

48.text: We’d measured the reeds in one particular place,

51.text: we were doing a fence line and we though oh gee

53.text: they’re reaching high there and we measured them and they were 18 feet.

56.text: (Garry Hall) My father came here in 1960 and my great-grandfather bought

60.text: the place in 1934 so our family has had

62.text: a long association with the marshes.

64.text: Growing up here as a kid in my memory of it it was pretty healthy.

71.text: Yeah birds everywhere, like now what

74.text: we call endangered I can clearly remember my

78.text: father scaring us as kids with the Brown Bittern,

82.text: Australasian Bittern that we’d hear booming during the summer

85.text: time and that was, he told us it was a bunyip

90.text: and we believed him. So Ibis colonies in the big

93.text: floods, yeah our family’s always had an interest in

97.text: nature and birds. As kids we were taught the link

102.text: between a healthy environment, a healthy landscape

105.text: and healthy production for our business.

110.text: (Debbie Love) The late 60’s government decided as

114.text: they had in many parts of the state to build a large

117.text: dam to secure water supplies for a growing population.

121.text: And one of the effects of that was that it

123.text: disrupted the flow of water into the marshes.

126.text: And that has had and continues to have ongoing effect

130.text: on the ecosystem by changing how much water arrives

134.text: here and the patterns with which it arrives here.

137.text: So the system is really still adjusting to that

140.text: quite significant change in the water supply.

145.text: (Sam Davis) Macquarie Marshes provides a mosaic

148.text: of really, really vital and important habitats

150.text: and we’re increasing our understanding on how

153.text: native fish use these mosaics of habitats.

157.text: So they use these areas for breeding, for feeding,

160.text: a conduit for travel, finding mates.

163.text: (Tim Hosking) The Macquarie- Cudgegong Environmental Flows

165.text: Reference Group was first formed officially in 2004.

169.text: Although it arose from other committees before that

172.text: where for a long period New South Wales Office of

175.text: Environment and Heritage or its predecessors liked to

178.text: get local input into environmental water decisions.

181.text: (Ian Rogan) The challenge for the Macquarie-Cudgegong Environmental

183.text: Flows Reference Group is to provide I think balanced

187.text: advice on the management of environmental water to achieve

191.text: a range of outcomes. Primarily of course good

194.text: environmental outcomes for the Macquarie Marshes

197.text: and the whole of the Macquarie-Cudgegong river system.

200.text: But given the competing interests for water in this valley

205.text: and every other valley we need to take into account social

209.text: and economic impacts as well as environmental benefits

212.text: of managing our environmental water and it’s in my view

216.text: really important that there is a diverse group of

220.text: people with a range of interests around the table

222.text: to provide advice on the best way to manage environmental water.

230.text: (Jane Judd) The outcomes thatwe’re really trying to maintain are the

234.text: core values of the Macquarie Marshes. They were much more extensive in the

240.text: past, they’re going to be important in the future, wetlands have disappeared

243.text: throughout huge areas of the world.

247.text: (Danielle Flakelar) We get to be engaged in water management

251.text: issues, be part of decision making and planning,

255.text: particularly about when water’s going to be

258.text: released, what we’re trying to achieve out of that

260.text: water, where it will be best utilised in that

264.text: particular season given the rains, was there rains

268.text: there before, was there water sent previously

271.text: and will ours enhance the water flow that had flown before it.

277.text: in the Macquarie goes back about 30 years.

279.text: And it was long recognised even as the dam

282.text: was being built that the changes that would happen

285.text: would have an effect on the marshes.

287.text: So from the early 80’s there’s been an environmental

291.text: water allowance for the Macquarie Marshes and over

295.text: time that’s grown as we’ve come to understand more

298.text: and more about the water requirements of the system.

301.text: (Tim Hosking) Part of achieving a maximum benefit from the water

303.text: is taking stock of the antecedent conditions that exist

308.text: before we send the water down and then making a plan

312.text: that really does respond to the environment’s needs in

315.text: that particular year but also over time, looking

318.text: back three to five years and forwards.

324.text: (Ian Rogan) The community expects that that large

327.text: volume of environmental water entitlement is

330.text: efficiently managed. Some years there’ll be lots

333.text: of environmental water available to use, other

336.text: years such as this much less. We need to as close

340.text: as possible I think replicate what would have

343.text: achieved in a naturally unregulated system but then again we need to

348.text: take into account that in a regulated river system

350.text: such as this there are many other competing uses

353.text: for water and we need to demonstrate efficiency

356.text: in the use of environmental water.

358.text: (Debbie Love) Often people think that the environment

360.text: gets more water or is treated differently to other water

365.text: uses but that’s not the case, we’re all subject to the same rules.

371.text: (Ken Harris) It’s well known that these

373.text: wetlands exist in a drying/wetting cycle over a

377.text: long period of time. They do go through prolonged

379.text: periods of dry before they have their big boom years.

382.text: But of course it’s important given the

385.text: natural wetting regime has been changed to have

388.text: events like the one we’re seeing at the moment

390.text: to keep them spinning along between their big boom years.

395.text: (Debbie Love) We know we can’t return

397.text: the marshes to what they were before Burrendong

400.text: Dam was built but we hope to maintain some of

404.text: the functions and values that the wetlands have.

407.text: (Jane Judd) The wetlands are an important

412.text: They are an essential part of the ecosystem.

417.text: (Garry Hall) I’m still optimistic that things will look

419.text: better in 10/20/50 years than they do now.
